At-a-Glance: After capture, a swarm needs quiet dark housing, feed if light, mite checks, and confirmation the queen is accepted and laying.
Why it Matters: Sets the colony up for hygienic comb and varroa control.
Objectives: Provide suitable volume and ventilation in a nuc or hive body.
Stabilise with feeders and a single entrance.
Verify queen-right status and apply mite management.
What Good Looks Like: Swarm housed the same day; sheltered and strapped.
Internal feed available; frames with guides or foundation ready.
Mite monitoring scheduled; queen laying within 1–2 weeks.
Step-by-Step: 1) Transfer swarm to nuc/hive with frames; keep dark/quiet 24–48 h.
2) Feed if there is no strong flow; avoid spills to deter robbing.
3) Add a queen excluder under brood box (temporary) if absconding risk is high; remove after comb is started.
4) Inspect at 7–10 days for comb start and eggs; avoid heavy smoke.
5) Monitor varroa and treat per label if indicated; log all actions.
Seasonality & Climate: Early swarms draw comb fast with flow; late swarms need more feed and insulation.
Wet/cool spells increase absconding and chill risks.
Data & Thresholds: Confirm eggs by day 7–10; if absent by day 14, reassess for queen issues.
Swarm weight vs box size: avoid over-volume that drives absconding.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Absconding signs -> Reduce entrance; add brood frame if available; ensure ventilation.
Symptom: No eggs at day 14 -> Introduce tested queen or brood; check for virgin timing.
Symptom: Heavy mites -> Treat promptly; plan comb renewal.
Common Pitfalls: Leaving collected swarms in hot cars or sunny spots.
No record of queen status or mite checks.
Tools & Techniques: Nuc boxes, internal feeders, strap, temporary floor excluder use.
Gentle entrance reduction and shade screens.
Safety & Compliance: Secure loads in vehicles; avoid public exposure during transfer.
Follow local treatment rules for new colonies.
Field Checklist: Housing prepared; feed installed if needed.
Communications: Explain to helpers that quiet and darkness discourage absconding.
Notes: A frame of open brood (if disease-safe) anchors swarms effectively.
